and Pedagogy, Intellectuals, and Dissent in the Later Middle Ages
and of articles on medieval literature, rhetoric and literary theory, and ancient and medieval intellectual cultures. She is a co-editor of the annual journal New Medieval Literatures

title: V irginia Cox is Professor of Italian at New York University. Her main interests are the history of rhetoric in medieval and Renaissance Italy, and early modem Italian women's writing. Her publications include The Renaissance Dialogue: Literary Dialogue in its Social and Political Contexts, Castiglione to Tasso

note: reprinted Tempe: Arizona Center for Medieval and Renaissance Studies, 2001). He has edited with Richard A. Katula, A Synoptic History o f Classical Rhetoric, 3rd edn (Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, 2003); and with Lawrence Green, Renaissance Rhetoric: A Short-Title Catalogue,
title: M urphy is Professor Emeritus of English and Rhetoric at the University of California, Davis. He was the founding Editor of Rhetorica: A Journal o f the History o f Rhetoric, published by the International Society for the History of Rhetoric. He is the author of Rhetoric in the Middle Ages

container-title: and Political Thought in Early Fourteenth-Century England (Medieval and Renaissance Texts and Studies, 2002). He is also one of the editors of the forthcoming New Dictionary o f the History o f Ideas
title: N ederman is Professor and Graduate Director in the Department of Political Science at Texas A&M University, College Station. Previously, he taught at the University of Arizona, Siena College, the University of Canterbury (NZ), and the University of Alberta. He has written or edited numerous books and articles, among the most recent of which are Worlds o f Difference: European Discourses o f Toleration, c.HOO-c.1550

container-title: entitled Perspectives on Early Modem and Modern Intellectual History: Essays in Honor o f Nancy S. Struever
title: Struever is Professor Emerita in the Department of History at The Johns Hopkins University. A noted historian of rhetoric, her books include The Language o f History in the Renaissance: Rhetoric and Historical Consciousness in Florentine Humanism
Theory as Practice: Ethical Inquiry in the Renaissance
and Language and the History o f Thought
She was recently presented with a Festschrift honouring her contributions to scholarship

note: and, with Michael Winterbottom, editions and translations of William of Malmesbury’s historical works for Oxford Medieval Texts.
title: T hom son is Emeritus Professor of Medieval History, and Honorary Research Associate in the School of History and Classics, University of Tasmania. He is interested in European intellectual history from 1000 to 1300, with particular attention to England's place in the Twelfth-Century Renaissance, Benedictine books and learning, satire, and the origins of universities. His publications include descriptive catalogues of the manuscripts at Lincoln, Hereford and Worcester Cathedrals, William o f Malmesbury
